consent.title: Welcome to Olympics Pilot Tug-of-War
content: Tug-of-war tournament judgments with strength/effort/prediction and commentary inputs embedded per trial.
This experiment should take about 20 minutes.
Your participation is completely voluntary. You can agree to take part and later change your mind.

content.value: In this experiment, you will see tug-of-war tournaments and make judgments about these tournaments.
In each match, players either compete as part of a team or individually. The crown indicates which team won the match.

Note that a player's strength remains constant throughout a tournament. A player neither gets better nor worse between matches.

However, each player can decide how much effort to put into each game. A player may put in low effort, high effort, or a normal amount of effort in a game.

The outcome depends on both the players' underlying ability and how much effort they put in on that match.

Note that we will show you a new set of players in each tournament.

On each trial, you will answer five questions on the right side of the screen:
  • Two questions about players' strength.
  • Two questions about how much effort players put into specific matches.
  • One question about who would win in a new hypothetical match.
You will respond to each question on a slider at the bottom of the screen. You can click on any point along the slider. Your task is to provide your best guess based on the available information.
We will next ask you a few questions to check that you understood the instructions.
Comprehension quiz: look at the tournament below. The next question asks: "Who won the above game?"

content.question: Which of the following statements is true based on the instructions given?
options: A player's strength and effort both remain constant between games.
A player's strength remains constant, and effort can change between games.
A player's strength can change, and effort remains constant between games.
A player's strength and effort both can change between games.

content.value:
The tug-of-war championships are a tournament consisting of several tug-of-war matches between teams of athletes.
Tug-of-war is a sport in which two teams of athletes compete by pulling on opposite ends of a rope.
The championships are open to anyone. Athletes vary widely in how strong they are in general. As with the general public, most athletes are average strength, though some can be much stronger and some can be much weaker.
How hard each athlete can pull the rope in each round usually depends on their general physical strength. Athletes with more strength can pull harder.
How hard each team pulls the rope in any given match depends largely on how hard all of the individual athletes pull on that team.
The team that pulls the hardest in a given match usually wins.
But remember, many other factors might come up in any particular match.
In the second part of the task, you will act as a sports commentator. You will see two tournaments again and add one sentence of new information about each tournament.

Your goal is to write a sentence that would change another participant's beliefs about what happened in the tournament. If you refer to a specific match, be sure to specify which one (e.g., first match or second match). You will also briefly explain why you think your sentence should have the intended effect.
